reviewText: Ridiculously long, some exams are atrocious, the final submission is massive.
outdated maerial and many articles are placed behind a subscription. My suggestion is not to follow this course

To be honest,  I am deeply disappointed. I endured only half-way through Module 2. The course is more or less mistaking "Leadership" with basic managerial skills required from C-level industry leaders. It has nothing to do with advanced Leadership concepts taught in business schools around the globe. Mistaking one for the other is one of the fallacies of unsuccessful CEOs. Many of the behaviours and actions shown in the videos would not have been compatible with the advanced industry leadership roles I held in the past. I am a CEO. On a more practical note, I was a bit annoyed that some of the mandatory reading materials required a subscription to The Wall Street Journal. Whilst not expensive for the trial period it still a bit ...well, annoying.
This course is boring. I want to unenroll this.
Not that 21st Century... Some of the materials are quite old and there is little "learning" and too much acting.. I'm not finding it helpful at all...

The course had good material but it is poorly maintained, too many broken links and links to articles behind paywalls. Would not recommend paying for until they update the course, seems like they just created it and then left it.

I do not recommend this course, it is five years old, many of the links no longer work and many more link to sites that require payments. I flagged all such occasions and reached out to instructors but they never got back to me. Some materials are good, but on balance I believe there are better courses on the same subject. Course needs to be updated!
Не понравился данный курс. Очень все непонятно и скучно, только временами была какая-то полезная информация для самостоятельного изучения.

The course covers diversified concepts and is an excellent attempt of throwing light on how to deal with the challenges that are faced by a 21st century leader. A well curated and systematic approach with examples that are relatable to real life problems demonstrating both sides of the problem. Although, a few links to certain Youtube videos from Stanford and have been made private and are not accessible to the applicants. The wall street journal articles are also only available on a pay to view basis. All in all its a really good course.

The theory and the practical examples are great and I gained a lot of valuable knowledge. However, some links to articles or videos are broken (not available anymore) and also the WLJ articles cannot be read without a subscription. Please revise the links because this make learning very difficult and even impossible to learn by reading. Teachers explanations and details are very professional and clear. The SMA example is wonderful and helps a lot seeing the theory applied in practice. The only thing is to please check and revise the broken links to make learning smother. Thank you.

Its a well built course based on a case study in the manufacturing and rather unique aircraft industry. The case study takes you through nearly all elements of challenges and decision making that leaders are presented with. Every module of this course can be used to think through your own approach in the presented situation and to understand your own style of leadership. Take time to read through the comments and submission of other learners - as some of those views are thought provoking as well.So whether you are starting your leadership journey in which case this course will give you a flavor of the decisions you will need to make OR if you are an experienced leader, but need a refresher - this course is worth your time.The comments I have to improve the course are 1) some video links are broken and need to be updated 2) the course material can be refreshed with newer elements (eg empathy in the workplace) 3) an ability to communicate with the professors to bounce off a couple of thoughts 4) Feedback and reviewing peer submissions / comments during the training on various topics rather than only on final submission should be compulsory  (say atleast 10 other peer reviews)

I definitely recommend this course. Lots of great material, and Robert D. Austin and Shannon Hessel are excellent professors. So, why 4 stars instead of 5? There were a number of things on this course that were not functional. Broken links, links to videos that go nowhere, and links to content behind pay walls, such as the Wall St. Journal. Each time I encountered one of these, I flagged it. Let's see if it would actually get fixed.With this class being self-paced, the discussion forums are kind of stale, although some interesting reads there. After taking this, I'm seriously interested in taking more of the Copenhagen Business school coursera courses on strategy.

I also, did not participate in any discussions, but perhaps if I had this course would have been rated 5 stars.

This course has very interesting way of teaching which professor called as dramatized episodes. Aspects of leadership like Strategy formulation, Leading in crisis, Managing talent, Leading collaboration, Communication in an age of radical transparency, Motivating and Inspiring, Effective governance, Leading change, Leading innovation, Leading execution, Stakeholder management, Public life & private life of CEO, etc. is narrated and acted by protagonist Jim Barton.
Another interesting way of presentation is that it is not recorded like a normal film. It is free of any special effects or production design. Though it is tried to disguise this as often as possible, one can see that the actors are reading from scripts. Professor explains that, It's common practice in the theater when someone want to develop new scripts and have limited time to do so, to produce what is called staged readings, where actors read from the script. It allow to concentrate on storytelling through dialogue between people without the fuss of a lot of visual production elements.

It is not  simply a  study material about  the twenty first century leadership concepts, it is much more exhaustive. Thanks for a great and interesting course. I enjoy Barton's history and how the course was structured with interesting readings and articles which provide more learning points. Definitely, I'd look for more CBS courses!!On the potential learnings side, I know it's difficult since I've done already a few online courses and the methodology is similar, but the forums does not encourage much debate or mentors challanging some of the mentioned ideas. We normally just write our opinion, independently of other students contribution which is not what we should do. Maybe some videoconference appointments could facilitate some real debates and more learning.Also, when possible, more time to prepare a good final work would be appreciated since to summarize so much content it's not easy and it requires time.In any case, as I said, highly recommended course, and methodology. Just looking forward for my next CBS course!

I would describe this course as very polished. A great deal of thought (and I am sure practice in front of the cameras) has went into production. It is a clear useful guide through the governance and leadership minefield. The messages are clear and well thought out. I have completed a great number of online courses (65 to date) and this course has to be on top of the list of genuinely useful ones. Everything comes across effortlessly only because of the work behind the scenes that has went into thinking how to do so.Please produce  more courses like this, please...

One of the best leadership courses I have participated in. Really good combination of theory and much emphasis on actual how to do and real world scenarios. Great course! If you are tired of the normal theory bla bla this is really a course for you. You learn a lot and then you get to follow Jim Barton on his journey from a bean counter to a CEO of a manufacturing company.
Innovative course content delivered with dramatized episodes. Definitely one of the best courses out there.
